reference.shortdesc: This topic documents the common definitions for attributes that appear within the DITA DTDs, and provides the content for reuse within the individual element descriptions of the DITA Language Reference .

section.p: Writers, please ensure that explanations are generic in nature. For example, references to specific instances of SGML such as DocBook or IBMIDDoc may not be meaningful to all readers. To avoid naming specific products, refer to them generically as "validating XML editors," and so on. Not all DITA users will implement DITA the same way or have the same markup language background when reading DITA documentation!

section.note: All DITA linking attributes defined as allowing URLs are defined as CDATA but should follow standard URL syntax (CDATA is used for now because DTDs cannot enforce a URL datatype). They are used literally in transforms, therefore the integrity of the link is up to the author.

section.note: SGML users may recognize that this is very similar to the conref mechanism in SGML (call CONLOC in IBMIDDoc) that uses only an empty start tag to indicate the placement of the referenced element. However, the rules of XML do not allow us to do conref as easily as the SGML standard permitted. Even when you have a conref attribute to pull in content, the element using conref must be valid within the document. In the case of a table, for example, the table element requires a tgroup child, which requires tbody, which requires at least one row, which requires at least one entry. In addition, the tgroup element requires the cols attribute to be specified. You will have to insert all of these elements in your source file, even though they will be discarded during processing. Validating editors will insert all of the required elements, although you may still need to ensure that required attributes contain at least a throwaway value.

Pertaining to the following declaration in topic.mod:<!ELEMENT topic (%title;, (%titlealts;)?, (%shortdesc;)?, (%prolog;)?, %body;, (%related-links;)?, (%topic-info-types;)* )> if the parameter entity topic-info-types in topic.dtd were declared as<!ENTITY % topic-info-types "no-topic-nesting">then the resulting authoring DTD would not allow the nesting of any child topics. As far as the DTD is concerned, this empty element takes the place of any nested topics. Using a null value for a parameter entity value is not allowed in DTD syntax, therefore the architecture provides this empty element as a required token in the syntax.

This attribute is used to reference an ID on a topic that can be reused. For example, you could create a series of topics in a compound (dita) or nested context for authoring convenience and then reference each topic individually into a new target location. During output processing, a lookup process will pull the contents of the first topic into the calling topic markup that has the conref attribute.
The conref value follows the same conventions as HTML for normal file links. To refer to target content in a different file, put the full URL of that topic before the # character.
Target elsewhere in the same file: conref="#topicid" In different file: conref="filename.xml" In different compound file: conref="filename.xml#topicid"
conref attributetopic

This attribute is used to reference an ID on content that can be reused. For example, you could create a <note> in a topic and then reference its ID (using conref) from a <note> in another topic. During output processing, a lookup process will pull the contents of the first note into the note that has the conref attribute.
The conref value follows the same conventions as HTML for what HTML calls a "fragment identifier"—a required "#" separator separates an optional filename from the fully qualified id (in the form topicid/elementid). To refer to target content in a different file, put the full URL of that topic before the # character.
Local target: conref="#topicid/elementid" In different file: conref="filename.xml#topicid/elementid"

The role attribute defines the role the target topic plays in relationship with the current topic. For example, in a parent/child relationship, the role would be "parent" when the target is the parent of the current topic, and "child" when the target is the child of the current topic. This structure could be used to sort and classify links at display time.
Allowable values are:
parent
Indicates a link to a topic that is a parent of the current topic.
child
Indicates a link to a direct child such as a directly nested or dependent topic.
sibling
Iindicates a link between two children of the same parent topic.
friend
Indicates a link to a similar topic that is not necessarily part of the same hierarchy.
next
Indicates a link to the next topic in a sequence.
previous
Indicates a link to the previous topic in a sequence.
cousin
Indicates a link to another topic in the same hierarchy that is not a parent, child, sibling, next, or previous.
ancestor
Indicates a link to a topic above the parent topic.
descendent
Indicates a link to a topic below a child topic.
sample
Deprecated.
external
Deprecated--use the scope="external" attribute to indicate external links..
other
Indicates any other kind of relationship or role. Enter that role as the value for the otherrole attribute.

Specifies the language of the element content. When no xml:lang value is supplied, the default value of English is assumed. For example, if there is a note element with the attribute xml:lang set to the value "es-es," then the label on the note, which is normally output as "Note" is now output in Spanish as "Nota." A list of supported values is given in xml:lang values.xml:lang attribute

This attribute is provided on <pre>, <lines>, and on elements derived from them.
